They seem thrilled to talk about how embryo donation is "choosing life" which I found tone-deaf as someone with friends who've gone through infertility and had up to 7 embryo transfers to get 2 live births.'}, {'url': 'https://www.nytimes.com/2024/02/15/health/cooper-surgical-ivf-embryos-lawsuits.html', 'content': 'Advertisement
Supported by
Botched I.V.F. Liquid Destroyed Embryos, Lawsuits Claim
Patients have filed eight lawsuits against CooperSurgical, a major fertility company, which has recalled the faulty product.
 The filing said that the company had notified affected clinics on Dec. 13, telling them that “performance issues may lead to impaired embryo development” and instructing customers to stop using the product.
 The plaintiffs claim that the three batches of media were missing a key nutrient, magnesium, a defect that stopped their embryos from developing and rendered them unusable.
 By Sarah Kliff and Azeen Ghorayshi
CooperSurgical, a major medical supply company, is facing a wave of lawsuits from patients who claim that one of its products destroyed embryos created with in vitro fertilization.
 The Food and Drug Administration posted a recall notice on Wednesday saying that nearly 1,000 bottles of culture media were affected, about half of which were purchased by clinics in the United States.'}, {'url': 'https://www.reddit.com/r/IFGameteDonorParents/comments/zb3xgl/any_experience_with_embryo_connections/', 'content': "I was told to expect around 9 months to match with a donor, but overall it sounds like a really easy process to submit our profiles for matching. I'm eager to hear any experiences, positive or negative, with using Embryo Connections. Thanks in advance. thought: The search results do not indicate that the website http://www.embryon.com/ is currently known for being a scam. Most of the content is unrelated to the domain in question, and there are no apparent scam reports. However, the absence of such reports does not necessarily indicate legitimacy. Given the information I have gathered so far, I should now know the final answer. The website appears to be an old domain that is no longer active in e-commerce or any business activities. There is no evidence of scam activities, such as unusually low prices, claims of free money, handling different products from common e-commerce websites, or inappropriate contact information. The privacy of customer information notation and payment methods could not be assessed due to the lack of content on the site. The information listed has not been updated, but that aligns with the claim that the business concluded operations in 2000. The URL http://www.embryon.com/ does not appear to be a scam website based on the available evidence and the characteristics of scam websites outlined.
